metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. M/s Shah Mohandas Sadhuram

facts.text: The assessee, M/s Shah Mohandas Sadhuram, is a firm consisting of four members: two majors (Atmaram and Doulatram, first and second members) and two minors (third and fourth members).
The four members were till 31-3-1952 members of a Joint Family, which divided on that date, each taking one-fourth share of assets and liabilities as per books of Seth Mohandas Sadhuram.
Partnership Deed executed on 1-4-1952 by majors, admitting minors to the benefits of the partnership but not to liabilities.
Firm to do business of Banking and Commerce, including Automobiles business under Vijaya Automobiles, Mysore, started by first and second members.
Equal capital contribution by each member, shown in personal capital ledger.
Profits distributed pro rata to capital after reserving six pies per rupee for Charity; losses shared similarly. Minors' shares credited to their accounts for maintenance.
Duration: one year from 1-4-1952 to 31-3-1953, continuable by agreement.
Separate accounting for Bombay branch and others outside Mysore.
Assessee claimed registration u/s 26A for 1953-54 on 1952 deed.
ITO rejected for 1953-54: minors made parties by eldest brother (guardian), minor debited with loss; partnership not entitled to registration.
Supplementary deed on 1-4-1953 extending partnership, filed on 10 annas stamp paper; ITO rejected for 1954-55 on original invalidity plus stamp issue.
AAC upheld ITO orders for both years.
Tribunal allowed registration for both years, construing deed as admitting minors to benefits only, following Jakka Devayya and Sons v. CIT Madras.
Tribunal referred question to Mysore HC at CIT instance.
Mysore HC answered in favor of assessee, following its judgment in ITR No.2/1959 (CIT Madras v. M/s Shah Jethaji Phulchand).
Certificate u/s 66A Income-tax Act 1922 granted by Mysore HC for appeals to SC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the assessee, Mohandas Sadhuram, can be granted registration under Section 26-A of the Indian Income Tax Act on the basis of the partnership deed made on 1-4-1952 for the assessment year 1953-54 and on the basis of the said deed read with the supplementary deed on 1-4-1953 for the assessment year 1954-55.

petitioner_arguments.text: On proper construction of the deed, minors have been made full partners, as per clauses 4, 7, 8, 10, 11 and 12.
Guardian is not entitled to contract on behalf of a minor and the deed is consequently void.
ITO can only register partnership as specified in instrument; cannot register different one. Document making minor full partner not valid for registration.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CIT Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan Co.; Section 30 Partnership Act

respondent_arguments.text: Instrument of partnership entered into between persons some incompetent to contract (minor) is not necessarily null and void; where guardian executes to admit minor to benefits, no invalidity.

court_reasoning.text: Guardian competent to contract on behalf of minor to secure full benefits of partnership under s.30 Partnership Act: accept benefits, contribute capital (avoidable if not beneficial), sever connection, elect terms of continuance, scrutinise terms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: As long as deed does not make minor full partner, not invalid merely because guardian contracted for benefits.

court_reasoning.text: Recital expressly states majors constitute partnership admitting minors to benefits only; construe clauses in that light.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clause 4 refers to agreement in recital.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 7 (capital): Guardian must accept or refuse terms of benefits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement valid unless avoided by minor.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 10 (duration): Fixed by majors; guardian agrees if beneficial; future terms must comply with law.
Deed reasonably construed confers benefits only, not full partnership; distinguishes Dwarkadas where minor treated as full partner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Guardian agreed to clauses to effectuate conferment of benefits.

holdings.text: Partnership deed only confers benefits of partnership on minors, does not make them full partners; valid for registration u/s 26A.
Income Tax authorities should not have declined registration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jakka Devayya and Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal followed Madras HC decision construing deed as admitting minors to benefits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. M/s Shah Jethaji Phulchand
precedents_cited.relevance: Mysore HC followed its own judgment; instrument not invalid if guardian admits minor to benefits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Facts different: minor described as full partner liable for losses, entitled to manage, vote etc.; here distinction made.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration of firm; reference to HC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admission of minor to benefits of partnership; guardian's powers to accept benefits, contribute capital, sever etc.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court agrees with Mysore High Court, holds firm entitled to registration under s.26A for both years; answer to referred question in affirmative.
outcome.relief_granted: Registration under s.26A granted to assessee for 1953-54 and 1954-55.

key_quotes.text: as long as a partnership deed does not make a minor full partner a partnership deed cannot be regarded as invalid on the ground that a guardian has purported to contract on behalf of a minor if the contract is for the purposes mentioned above.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on validity of deed with guardian acting for minor's benefits.

key_quotes.text: the partnership deed, reasonably construed, only confers benefits of partnership on the two minors and does not make them full partners.
key_quotes.speaker: court
